subject: Investing
title: Capitulation: The Psychology of Giving Up
description: A micro-lesson that makes Capitulation: The Psychology of Giving Up usable.

hook.text: In March 2009, investors pulled a record $54 billion from stock funds. The market bottomed that same month.

buildup.text: Capitulation is when the last holdouts surrender and sell, often marking the end of a decline.

discovery.text: Volume spikes and extreme pessimism in sentiment surveys are classic capitulation signals.

twist.text: The moment selling pressure exhausts itself is precisely when recovery beginsâ€”but nobody feels like buying.

climax.text: Contrarian investors who buy during capitulation events have historically earned outsized returns.

punchline.text: The best time to invest feels like the worst. That's the price of the premium.

quiz.question: What typically happens after market capitulation?
